documents.text:
Case 2:18-cv-01122-BHS   Document 1   Filed 07/31/18   Page 1 of 68
 
  THE HONORABLE        
1 
2 
3 
4 
5 
6   
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
7  WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON 
AT SEATTLE 
8   
PARS EQUALITY CENTER;  )
9  ONEAMERICA; PAMELA WHITEHALL  )
RAGHEBI; AFSHIN RAGHEBI; ZEINAB  )
10  MOHAMED HASSAN; SIRAJI ETHA  )
SIRAJI; MALAYEEN AHMED; REZA  )
11  AZIMI; YAHYA GHALEB; MITRA  )
HANNANI; NICHOLAS HANOUT;  )
12  HOSSEIN ZAMANI HOSSEINABADI;  )
HODA MEHRABI MOHAMMADABADI;  )
13  JOHN DOES #1-3; and JANE DOE #1,  )
Case No. __________ 
  )
 
14  Plaintiffs,  )
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT 
  )
 
15  v.  )
 
  )
16  MIKE POMPEO; KIRSTJEN NIELSEN;  )
KEVIN K. MCALEENAN; U.S.  )
17  DEPARTMENT OF HOMELAND  )
SECURITY; U.S. DEPARTMENT OF  )
18  STATE; and U.S. CUSTOMS AND  )
BORDER PROTECTION,  )
19    )
Defendants.  )
20    ) 
21  INTRODUCTION 
22  1.  This lawsuit challenges Defendants’ implementation of the waiver provision of 
23  Presidential  Proclamation  No.  9645,  “Enhancing  Vetting  Capabilities  and  Processes  for 
24  Detecting Attempted Entry into the United States By Terrorists or other Public-Safety Threats” 
25  (“Proclamation”). The Proclamation indefinitely bans millions of nationals of five Muslim-
26  majority countries from entering the United States. For many thousands of individuals and 
27  families indefinitely separated by the President’s ban, the Proclamation’s waiver provision has, 
LANE POWELL PC 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT - 1 
1420 FIFTH AVENUE, SUITE 4200 
NO.   P.O. BOX 91302 
SEATTLE, WA 98111-9402 
206.223.7000  FAX: 206.223.7107 
 

 
  Case 2:18-cv-01122-BHS   Document 1   Filed 07/31/18   Page 2 of 68
 
1  as a practical matter, amounted to nothing more than an empty promise—in the words of Justice 
2  Breyer, merely “window dressing.” 
3  2.  Under the Proclamation, the only way that banned individuals can now gain 
4  entry to the United States is by obtaining a waiver. See Section 3(c), Proc. No. 9645 (hereinafter 
5  “waiver provision”). But the Proclamation’s waiver provision has been implemented in such a 
6  haphazard, opaque, and capricious manner, and so few visa applicants have actually been 
7  granted waivers under the Proclamation, that the process by which waivers are supposedly 
8  granted has become part and parcel of the ban itself.  
9  3.  Indeed, a former consular official and State Department employee has stated in 
10  a sworn declaration “that there really is no waiver,” because consular officers have been 
11  instructed “to determine at all possible cost that the [visa applicant] was not eligible to even 
12  apply for the waiver.” See Exhibit A. 
13  4.  What  is  publicly  known  about  Defendants’  implementation  of  the 
14  Proclamation’s waiver provision is consistent with this assessment. 
15  5.  When the Proclamation went into effect, there were mass denials of waivers, 
16  regardless of whether the applicant had already had a consular interview, whether the applicant 
17  had any meaningful notice of the availability of a waiver, or whether the applicant had an 
18  opportunity to present evidence of eligibility for a waiver. 
19  6.  There is no application form for a waiver from the Proclamation’s ban. There is 
20  no information about how an individual seeking a visa can demonstrate his or her eligibility 
21  under the criteria set out in the Proclamation. There is no formal opportunity provided in the 
22  visa application process for an individual to demonstrate eligibility for a waiver. Nor do there 
23  appear to be consistent processes by which to accept and consider requests for waivers. 
24  7.  As implemented by Defendants, moreover, the process and standard by which 
25  waivers are granted are dramatically different from what the Proclamation sets out. The few 
26  public disclosures about how the State Department is implementing the Proclamation’s waiver 
27  provision  indicate  that  consular  officers  are  assessing  visa  applicants’  waiver  eligibility 
LANE POWELL PC 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT - 2 
1420 FIFTH AVENUE, SUITE 4200 
NO.   P.O. BOX 91302 
SEATTLE, WA 98111-9402 
206.223.7000  FAX: 206.223.7107 
 

 
  Case 2:18-cv-01122-BHS   Document 1   Filed 07/31/18   Page 3 of 68
 
1  pursuant to an arbitrary and ad hoc process, and under far narrower criteria than those actually 
2  set forth in the Proclamation. Numerous individuals—including every individual Plaintiff in 
3  this action—fall within the circumstances identified by the Proclamation as warranting a waiver, 
4  but have nevertheless been unable to obtain a waiver. 
5  8.  Given the unduly restrictive manner in which Defendants have implemented the 
6  Proclamation’s waiver provision, families from the five majority-Muslim banned countries 
7  remain unnecessarily separated, and cannot celebrate traditional milestones together like births, 
8  graduations,  weddings,  and  birthdays,  or  provide  support  through  illness  and  hardship. 
9  Institutions of higher learning cannot bring academics and students from the banned countries 
10  to pursue research or study in the United States. Employers are unable to hire or employ 
11  qualified individuals from the banned countries. 
12  9.  The plaintiffs in this lawsuit are individuals facing indefinite separation from 
13  their families, for whom a waiver from the ban is the only way they can reunite with their 
14  families, and organizations who serve individuals in similar straits. They respectfully request 
15  that the Court enjoin Defendants from implementing or enforcing any part of the Proclamation’s 
16  waiver provision in a manner that violates the Administrative Procedure Act (“APA”), the INA, 
17  the Constitution, or the Proclamation itself. 
18  JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
19  10.  This Court has subject matter jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C. §§ 1331 and 1343 
20  over Plaintiffs’ claims under the U.S. Constitution and federal statutes. The Court has additional 
21  remedial authority under 28 U.S.C. §§ 2201-02. 
22  11.  Venue is proper under 28 U.S.C. § 1391(e) and Local Rule § 104(e). Defendants 
23  are officers or employees of the United States acting in their official capacities, and agencies of 
24  the  United  States.  Organizational  Plaintiff  OneAmerica  and  individual  plaintiffs  Pamela 
25  Whitehall Raghebi, Zeinab Mohamed Hassan, and Siraji Etha Siraji reside in the Seattle 
26  Division of this District. No real property is involved in this action. 
27 
LANE POWELL PC 
CLASS ACTION COMPLAINT - 3 
1420 FIFTH AVENUE, SUITE 4200 
NO.   P.O. BOX 91302 
SEATTLE, WA 98111-9402 
206.223.7000  FAX: 206.223.7107 
 

 
  Case 2:18-cv-01122-BHS   Document 1   Filed 07/31/18   Page 4 of 68
 
1  PARTIES 
2  12.  The Plaintiffs in this case are both individuals and organizations. The individual 
3  plaintiffs are United States citizens and foreign nationals lawfully present in the United States,  
4  whose efforts to reunite here with relatives abroad have been delayed or indefinitely thwarted 
5  by the President’s executive orders (“EOs”)1 and by Defendants’ implementation of the waiver 
6  provision; individuals abroad who have been left with no avenue to reunite with family and 
7  loved ones in the United States because of the EOs and the Proclamation’s waiver requirement; 
8  and legally present foreign nationals from countries subject to the Proclamation who, but for 
9  the uncertainty created by the waiver process, wish to travel abroad and return to the United 
10  States. 
11  13.  Some individual plaintiffs have approved I-130 immigrant petitions for their 
12  relatives abroad; of these, some are awaiting a decision on their immigrant visa applications 
13  and a waiver, while others have already been denied waivers and visas. Other plaintiffs are 
14  foreign nationals who have filed nonimmigrant visa petitions to visit and reunite with loved 
15  ones present in the United States, and who are either awaiting a decision or have been denied 
16  waivers and visas. 
17  14.  All the individual plaintiffs have been forced to endure a prolonged separation 
18  from their loved ones because of the EOs and, now, Defendants’ unlawful implementation of 
19  the Proclamation’s waiver provision. 
20  15.  The organizational plaintiffs serve individuals or have members and clients who, 
21  like the individual plaintiffs, are United States citizens or lawful permanent residents with 
22  relatives abroad who are nationals of a banned country and who are seeking immigrant or 
23  nonimmigrant visas. The organizational plaintiffs assert standing on their own behalf, and 
24  plaintiff Pars Equality Center also asserts standing on behalf of its clients. 
                                                 
25 
1 Exec. Order 13769, Protecting the Nation From Foreign Terrorist Entry Into the United States, 82 Fed. Reg. 
8977 (Jan. 27, 2017) (hereinafter “EO-1”); Exec. Order 13780, Protecting the Nation From Foreign Terrorist 
26 
Entry Into the United States, 82 Fed. Reg. 13209 (Mar. 6, 2017) (hereinafter “EO-2”); Proc. No. 9645, Enhancing 
Vetting Capabilities and Processes for Detecting Attempted Entry into the United States by Terrorists or Other 
27 
Public Safety Threats, 82 Fed. Reg. 45161 (Sept. 24, 2017) (collectively, the “EOs” or the “Orders”).

3  46.  Defendant U.S. Department of Homeland Security (“DHS”) is a cabinet-level 
4  department of the United States federal government. Its components include U.S. Citizenship 
5  and  Immigration  Services  (“USCIS”),  Customs  and  Border  Protection  (“CBP”),  and 
6  Immigration and Customs Enforcement (“ICE”). USCIS’s responsibilities include adjudicating 
7  requests for immigration benefits for individuals located within the United States. CBP’s 
8  responsibilities include inspecting and admitting immigrants and nonimmigrant arriving with 
9  U.S.  visas  at  international  points  of  entry,  including  airports  and  land  borders.  ICE’s 
10  responsibilities include enforcing federal immigration law within the interior of the United 
11  States. The Proclamation assigns DHS a variety of responsibilities regarding its enforcement, 
12  including the implementation of the Proclamation’s waiver provision. 
13  47.  Defendant U.S. Department of State (“DOS”) is a cabinet-level department of 
14  the United States federal government. DOS is responsible for the issuance of immigrant and 
15  nonimmigrant  visas  abroad.  The  Proclamation  assigns  DOS  a  variety  of  responsibilities 
16  regarding  its  enforcement,  including  the  implementation  of  the  Proclamation’s  waiver 
17  provision. 
18  48.  Defendant Customs and Border Protection is a federal law enforcement agency 
19  within  DHS.  CBP’s  responsibilities  include  inspecting  and  admitting  immigrants  and 
20  nonimmigrant arriving with U.S. visas at international points of entry, including airports and 
21  land  borders.  The  Proclamation  assigns  CBP  a  variety  of  responsibilities  regarding  its

1  the latest of three attempts to effectuate President Trump’s oft-repeated campaign promise to 
2  implement a “total and complete shutdown of Muslims entering the United States.” 
3  50.  The  first  attempt,  EO-1,  was  signed  one  week  after  President  Trump’s 
4  inauguration. 82 Fed. Reg. 8977 (Jan. 27, 2017). 
5  51.  EO-1 banned for 90 days the entry of any national from seven Muslim-majority 
6  countries, banned the entry of all refugees for 120 days, and indefinitely banned the entry of all 
7  Syrian refugees. It was rushed into effect so quickly that it blindsided not only key members of 
8  the Cabinet but also the agencies charged with its implementation, causing chaos at airports 
9  across the nation and confusion among the ranks of U.S. Custom and Border Protection, the 
10  Department of Homeland Security, and the Department of State. 
11  52.  Although EO-1 was soon enjoined after it was issued, President Trump was 
12  undeterred. On March 6, 2017, he signed EO-2, which was extremely similar to EO-1 in most 
13  material respects and, according to Trump Administration officials, was intended to achieve the 
14  same policy outcomes as EO-1. After facing further successful legal challenges to EO-2, 
15  President Trump replaced it with the Proclamation on September 24, 2017. 
16  The September 24, 2017 Presidential Proclamation 
53.  The Proclamation, which went into effect on or around December 8, 2017, states 
17 
that all nationals seeking entry as immigrants from five Muslim-majority countries (Iran, Libya, 
18 
Somalia, Syria, and Yemen) are banned indefinitely. 
19 
54.  The Proclamation likewise indefinitely bans non-immigrant entry for  most 
20 
nationals from these countries, either by banning non-immigrant entry entirely (Syria), banning 
21 
entry based on the most commonly used non-immigrant visas for nationals from the affected 
22 
countries (Iran, Libya, Yemen), or subjecting non-immigrant visas applicants to “additional 
23 
scrutiny” (Somalia).3

The Proclamation’s Waiver Provision 
1 
61.  Like its predecessors, the Proclamation allows for waivers to its entry bans on a 
2 
case-by-case basis. Proclamation § 3(c). 
3 
62.  The Proclamation’s waiver provision states that a foreign national may be 
4 
granted a waiver if she satisfies three criteria: first, that “denying entry” would cause her “undue 
5 
hardship;” second, that her “entry would not pose a threat to the national security or public 
6 
safety of the United States;” and third, that her “entry would be in the national interest.” 
7 
Proclamation § 3(c)(i). 
8 
63.  The visa applicant has the burden of “demonstrat[ing] to the consular officer’s 
9 
or CBP official’s satisfaction” that the applicant meets each of the three criteria set out in 
10 
Section 3(c)(i). 
11 
64.  The Proclamation also provides nine examples of circumstances in which a 
12 
waiver might be appropriate, “such as” when a visa applicant “seeks to enter the United States 
13 
to visit or reside with a close family member . . . who is a United States citizen;” “seeks to 
14 
reenter the United States to resume” long-term work or study; “has previously established 
15 
significant contacts with the United States;” or “is an infant, a young child or adoptee” or “an 
16 
individual needing urgent medical care.” Proclamation § 3(c)(iv)(A)-(J). 
17 
65.  The waiver provision gives discretion to grant waivers specifically to consular 
18 
officers, the Commissioner of Customs and Border Protection, or a “designee” of the CBP 
19 
Commissioner. It further states that “a waiver may be granted only if a foreign national 
20 
demonstrates to the consular officer’s or CBP official’s satisfaction that” the foreign national 
21 
meets the three eligibility criteria (emphasis added). 
22 
66.  In  addition,  the  Proclamation  states  that  “[t]he  Secretary  of  State  and  the 
23 
Secretary  of  Homeland  Security  shall  coordinate  to  adopt  guidance  addressing  the 
24 
circumstances in which waivers may be appropriate for foreign nationals seeking entry as 
25 
immigrants or nonimmigrants.” Proclamation § 3(c)(ii) (emphasis added). 
26 
27

4  the national security or public safety of the United States;” 
5  B) “determining whether the entry of a foreign national would be in the national 
6  interest;” 
7  C) “addressing and managing the risks of making such a determination in light of

11  D) “assessing whether the United States has access, at the time of the waiver

15  E) “determining the special circumstances that would justify granting a waiver” as

17  (A)-(E) (emphasis added).

10  78.  According to the February 22 letter, “[i]f an applicant from one of the designated

99.  The lack of information provided either in the Proclamation or in subsequent 
5 
government statements about how waivers will be granted has resulted in a waiver process that 
6 
is opaque, confusing, arbitrary, and untethered to the Proclamation itself, to say nothing of 
7 
existing immigration laws and regulations. 
8 
100.  Indeed, the implementation of the Proclamation’s waiver provision appears to 
9

10 
itself. 
11 
101.  Upon information and belief, hundreds, if not thousands, of denials6 of waivers 
12 
were issued via standardized form letters in the first month after the Proclamation went into 
13 
effect on or around December 8, 2017. 
14

15 
of any particular individual’s visa application. Denials were sent to individuals who had already 
16 
completed their consular interviews; to individuals who had scheduled but had not yet appeared 
17 
for their consular interviews; and to individuals who had not  yet been offered consular 
18 
interviews. 
19 
103.  None of these individuals who received waiver denials were given notice of the 
20 
availability of a waiver or an opportunity to demonstrate their eligibility for such a waiver.

104.  The mass form denials extended even to individuals, such as Plaintiff Yahya 
22 
Ghaleb’s son, who had previously received verbal or written notice that their visa applications

discretion may not be circumscribed by the Secretary of State. 
24 
292.  Defendants’ actions, as set forth above, violate agency procedures, including 
25 
those found at 22 C.F.R. §§ 41.121 and 42.81, which state that when refusing the issuance of a

(Due Process, Fifth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution)

or other opportunity to provide evidence of their eligibility for a waiver, in contravention of 22

3  thus  no  discretion  over  whether  they  may  grant  a  visa  to  an  individual  subject  to  the 
4  Proclamation, in contravention of the Proclamation itself as well as 8 U.S.C. § 1104(a), which 
5  states that consular officers have complete discretion over the issuance of visas and that such 
6  discretion may not be circumscribed by the Secretary of State. 
7  300.  The Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution 
8  provides that “[n]o person . . . shall be deprived of life, liberty, or property, without due process 
9  of law.”  
10  301.  Congress has created statutory rights related to the petitioning for and issuance 
11  of visas and other immigration benefits.  
12  302.  Federal agencies have created regulatory rights related to the petitioning for and 
13  issuance of visas and other immigration benefits. 
14  303.  Individuals must be given due process prior to the deprivation of these statutory 
15  and regulatory rights. 
16  304.  Additionally,  United  States  citizens  and  lawful  permanent  residents  have 
17  constitutionally protected liberty interests in family reunification and in the ability of their 
18  family members to travel to the United States. Individuals must be given due process prior to 
19  any deprivation of these liberty interests.  
20  305.  Defendants’ actions, as set forth above, deprive individuals, including Plaintiffs 
21  and their members or clients, of the aforementioned statutory and regulatory rights, and liberty 
22  interests, without due process. 
23  306.  Defendants’ actions, as set forth above, thus violate the procedural due process 
24  guarantee of the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment.

2  implementing and enforcing Section 3(c) of the Presidential Proclamation to 
3  date, including the issuance of internal guidance, have been arbitrary, capricious, 
4  and otherwise in violation of law, including Section 3(c)(ii) of the Proclamation; 
5  B.  Enjoin Defendants, their officials, agents, employees, assigns, and all persons 
6  acting in concert or participating with them from implementing or enforcing any 
7  portion of Section 3(c) of the Proclamation in a manner that violates the APA, 
8  INA, the U.S. Constitution, or Section 3(c) of the Proclamation;

10  3(c) of the Presidential Proclamation;

13  policies, and procedures” for determining whether an applicant is entitled to a 
14  waiver under Section 3(c), and which comports with the APA, the INA, the U.S. 
15  Constitution, and Section 3(c) of the Proclamation;

17  and agents, as well as any other government employee, officer, or agent involved 
18  in deciding whether a waiver should be granted to consider all pending and

21  and agents, as well as any other government employee, officer, or agent involved

23  applicants who had been denied or refused waivers before this Court’s injunction

26  as proposed herein;

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 152   Filed 06/05/20   Page 1 of 10
 
1

4  UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
5  NORTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
6   
FARANGIS EMAMI, et al.,  Case No.  18-cv-01587-JD    
7 
 
Plaintiffs, 
8   
ORDER RE MOTIONS TO DISMISS 
v. 
9  OR FOR SUMMARY JUDGMENT  
 
KIRSTJEN NIELSEN, et al.,  Re: Dkt. No. 98 
10 
Defendants. 
11 
 
12 
a   
tr in PARS EQUALITY CENTER, et al.,  Case No. 18-cv-07818-JD    
uoro 13   
C tfila Plaintiffs,   
cC 14 
i
rts fo v.  Re: Dkt. No. 120 
iD tc 15   
 sir MIKE POMPEO, et al., 
et
tatsiD 16 
S d nr Defendants. 
ee 17 
th    
intr
UoN 18  These related cases concern Presidential Proclamation 9645, “Enhancing Vetting 
19  Capabilities and Processes for Detecting Attempted Entry Into the United States by Terrorists or 
20  Other Public-Safety Threats.”  82 Fed. Reg. 45161 (2017) (the “Proclamation”).  The 
21  Proclamation sharply curtailed, and in some cases completely suspended, entry into the United 
22  States by nationals of Chad, Iran, Libya, North Korea, Syria, Venezuela, Yemen and Somalia.  Id. 
23  at 45162, 45165-67.1  Plaintiffs focus on nationals of Iran, Libya, Somalia, Syria and Yemen, and 
24  challenge the government’s handling of a waiver program that would allow exceptions for entry 
25  into the United States in certain circumstances.  The gravamen of the complaints is that the 
26 
27 
 
1 The restrictions on nationals of Chad have been lifted.  Presidential Proclamation No. 9723, 83 
28 
Fed. Reg. 15937 (Apr. 10, 2018). 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 152   Filed 06/05/20   Page 2 of 10
 
1  government created guidance for waivers which it has systematically ignored to deny the vast 
2  majority of waiver applications.   
3  The Court granted in part and denied in part a motion to dismiss in the Emami case with 
4  leave to amend, finding that plaintiffs had plausibly stated a claim under the Accardi doctrine.  
5  Dkt. No. 74 (Emami) at 16.  The heart of this claim was that “the State Department has acted 
6  arbitrarily and unlawfully by disregarding its own procedures and rules in administering the 
7  waiver program” established by the Proclamation.  Id. at 14.  The Emami plaintiffs filed a second 
8  amended complaint.  Dkt. No. 75 (Emami).  As the Emami motion to dismiss proceedings were 
9  under way, the Pars case was transferred here from the Western District of Washington.  Dkt. No. 
10  80 (Pars).  The operative complaint in that case remains the initial complaint.  Dkt. No. 1 (Pars).  
11  Defendants have filed motions to dismiss, or to obtain summary judgment for, the second 
12  amended complaint in Emami and the complaint in Pars.  Dkt. No. 98 (Emami); Dkt. No. 120 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  (Pars).  This order resolves those motions.   
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  DISCUSSION 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  The parties’ familiarity with the record is assumed.  The prior dismissal order provides a 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  detailed statement of the case and plaintiffs’ claims, and the governing standards for a motion to 
S d nr
ee 17  dismiss.  Dkt. No. 74 (Emami).   
th
intr
Uo
N 18  I.  MOTIONS TO DISMISS 
19  A.  Pars Complaint 
20  The Court has not been called upon to review the plausibility of the Pars complaint until 
21  now.  The analysis of the Emami complaint in the dismissal order applies in full measure here, and 
22  streamlines the discussion. 
23  1.  Justiciability 
24  The Court squarely answered the government’s justiciability objection in Emami.  
25  Dismissal for lack of a justiciable controversy was denied because the Emami plaintiffs are not 
26  suing over “individual consular officer decisions on the merits . . . [or] the outcome of any 
27  particular consular officer’s decision in a given case.”  Dkt. No. 74 (Emami) at 11-12.  They are 
28  “challenging systemic practices with respect to the waiver program, and not individualized 
2 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 152   Filed 06/05/20   Page 3 of 10
 
1  determinations for any specific person.”  Id. at 12.  So too in the Pars complaint.  See Dkt. No. 1 
2  (Pars); Dkt. No. 125 (Pars) at 6 (“Plaintiffs do not seek review of any individual, discretionary 
3  decision by a consular officer,” rather, “they seek review of the policies and practices that 
4  Defendants have adopted to implement the Proclamation”).  This is a justiciable controversy 
5  properly before the Court.   
6  2.  APA Claim 
7  Defendants’ request to dismiss the APA claim in Pars is denied.  Defendants say that the 
8  APA does not apply at all.  Dkt. No. 120 (Pars) at 9-10.  But as the Court has already determined, 
9  the Administrative Procedure Act “creates a ‘basic presumption of judicial review for one 
10  suffering legal wrong because of agency action,’” and our circuit has construed the APA “to 
11  provide for ‘broad judicial review of agency action.’”  Dkt. No. 74 (Emami) at 13 (quoting 
12  Weyerhaeuser Co. v. U.S. Fish and Wildlife Serv., 139 S.Ct. 361, 370 (2018), and Regents of the 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  Univ. of Cal. v. U.S. Dep’t of Homeland Sec., 908 F.3d 476, 494 (9th Cir. 2018)).  Agency action 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  is not immunized from review just because it might be linked to a Presidential Proclamation.  See 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  East Bay Sanctuary Covenant v. Trump, 932 F.3d 742, 770 (9th Cir. 2018) (“insofar as DOJ and 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  DHS have incorporated the Proclamation by reference into the Rule, we may consider the validity 
S d nr
ee 17  of the agency’s proposed action, including its ‘rule . . . or the equivalent’”); Chamber of 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  Commerce of the U.S. v. Reich, 74 F.3d 1322, 1326 (D.C. Cir. 1996) (“agency regulations that 
19  implement an executive order are reviewable under the APA”). 
20  The Pars complaint is based on a final agency action properly subject to judicial review.  
21  Defendants say that plaintiffs have “fail[ed] . . . to direct their complaint against any ‘final agency 
22  action,’” Dkt. No. 128 (Pars) at 2-3, but that is not a fair characterization of plaintiffs’ complaint.  
23  The Pars plaintiffs have identified, and are challenging, a final agency action consisting of “the 
24  ‘worldwide guidance’ referenced in the State Department’s February 22 letter and the State 
25  Department guidance, cables, sample Q’s & A’s and instructions referenced in the Richardson 
26  declaration,” along with other actions taken by defendants in reliance of Section 3(c) of the 
27  Proclamation.  Dkt. No. 1 (Pars) ¶¶ 279-80.  Plaintiffs further allege that these actions resulted in 
28  a waiver process in which, among other things, “visa applicants have been denied waivers without 
3 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 152   Filed 06/05/20   Page 4 of 10
 
1  ever having received notice of a waiver process, and/or have been denied waivers without ever 
2  having had a consular interview or other opportunity to provide evidence of their eligibility for a 
3  waiver, in contravention of 22 C.F.R. §§ 41.121 and 42.81, which state that when refusing the 
4  issuance of a visa, a consular officer must inform the visa applicant ‘whether there is, in law or 
5  regulations, a mechanism (such as a waiver) to overcome the refusal.’”  Id. ¶ 281 (quoting 22 
6  C.F.R. § 41.121(b)(1)).  Plaintiffs also allege that the government has implemented a waiver 
7  process in which “consular officers do not have discretion over whether and when to grant a 
8  waiver, and thus no discretion over whether they may grant a visa to an individual subject to the 
9  Proclamation, in contravention of the Proclamation itself as well as 8 U.S.C. § 1104(a), which 
10  states that consular officers have complete discretion over the issuance of visas and that such 
11  discretion may not be circumscribed by the Secretary of State.”  Id. ¶ 284.   
12  Defendants suggest that “the Proclamation [is] the only relevant source of law in this 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  case,” Dkt. No. 128 (Pars) at 2-3, but plaintiffs have identified a number of legal tests with which 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  to assay the government’s conduct, and defendants have not demonstrated that plaintiffs have 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  missed the mark.  In effect, plaintiffs are following Trump v. Hawaii, 138 S.Ct. 2392, 2408 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  (2018), where the Supreme Court measured the Proclamation against the provisions of the 
S d nr
ee 17  Immigration and Nationality Act, even after finding that the President had lawfully exercised his 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  “broad discretion to suspend the entry of aliens into the United States” under § 1182(f) of that 
19  statute.  See Hawaii, 138 S.Ct. at 2411 (“We may assume that § 1182(f) does not allow the 
20  President to expressly override particular provisions of the INA.  But plaintiffs have not identified 
21  any conflict between the statute and the Proclamation”).  In this case, plaintiffs have plausibly 
22  alleged conflicts between the government’s actions, 22 C.F.R. §§ 41.121 and 42.81, the 
23  Proclamation, and 8 U.S.C. § 1104(a).  Defendants effectively concede the point by sidestepping 
24  the conflict allegations with factual arguments, such as “each Plaintiff received exactly what the 
25  regulations require,” Dkt. No. 120 (Pars) at 11, and “Plaintiffs are wrong that consular officers are 
26  denied discretion to grant waivers,” Dkt. No. 128 (Pars) at 7. 
27  The Court also declines to dismiss at this juncture plaintiffs’ allegation that defendants’ 
28  implementation of the waiver provision violated the APA’s notice-and-comment requirements.  
4 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 152   Filed 06/05/20   Page 5 of 10
 
1  Dkt. No. 125 (Pars) at 11; Dkt. No. 1 (Pars) ¶ 287 (“Defendants’ actions, as set forth above, affect 
2  the Plaintiffs’ substantive rights and were made without observance of procedure required by law 
3  in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act, 5 U.S.C. § 706(2)(D).”).  “[W]hen an agency 
4  promulgates regulations other than ‘interpretative rules, general statements of policy, or rules of 
5  agency organization, procedure, or practice,’ 5 U.S.C. § 553(b)(A), the statute provides the public 
6  with pre-promulgation notice and comment.  5 U.S.C. § 553(b), (c).”  Alcaraz v. Block, 746 F.2d 
7  593, 610-11 (9th Cir. 1984) (internal citation omitted).  The government cites Innovation Law Lab 
8  v. McAleenan, 924 F.3d 503, 509 (9th Cir. 2019), for the proposition that the State Department’s 
9  waiver guidance was not required to go through notice-and-comment rulemaking because it was 
10  merely “a ‘general statement of policy’ to guide the exercise of discretion by its officials.”  Dkt. 
11  No. 128 (Pars) at 6.  But that is not consistent with plaintiffs’ allegations here.  Plaintiffs have 
12  plausibly alleged for 12(b)(6) purposes that defendants have issued guidance which resulted in a 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  waiver process in which consular officers had no discretion to exercise at all.  Dkt. No. 1 (Pars) 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  ¶¶ 279, 284.  The government may, however, raise the argument again if warranted at a later stage 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  of the case, after development of the record.   
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  3.  Accardi Claim 
S d nr
ee 17  As a second claim, the Pars plaintiffs essentially re-allege their first claim in the 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  alternative, this time under the “Accardi Doctrine & Administrative Procedure Act.”  Dkt. No. 1 
19  (Pars) ¶¶ 289-94.  It will go forward for the reasons stated in the Emami order with respect to the 
20  Accardi doctrine.  The government says that “Accardi has no relevance here, where the 
21  Proclamation and its related guidance are neither regulations nor internal documents that create 
22  any procedural rights.”  Dkt. No. 120 (Pars) at 10.  This is in effect an improper request for 
23  reconsideration of the Emami order, see Civil L.R. 7-9, and in any event, the Accardi doctrine is 
24  not so circumscribed, as the government’s own case citations demonstrate.  In Montilla v. 
25  Immigration and Naturalization Service, 926 F.2d 162, 167 (2d Cir. 1991), the court held that 
26  “[t]he Accardi doctrine is premised on fundamental notions of fair play underlying the concept of 
27  due process.  . . . Its ambit is not limited to rules attaining the status of formal regulations.  As the 
28  Supreme Court noted ‘where the rights of individuals are affected, it is incumbent upon agencies 
5 

Case 3:18-cv-01587-JD   Document 152   Filed 06/05/20   Page 6 of 10
 
1  to follow their own procedures.’”  The Montilla court further noted that “[t]he doctrine has 
2  continued vitality, particularly where a petitioner’s rights are ‘affected.’”  Id. 
3  Two other aspects of the Montilla case are relevant here.  It does not stand for the 
4  proposition, as the government suggests, that “even assuming that an Accardi claim could survive 
5  a motion to dismiss, the only relief available would be limited to a ‘remand’ with instructions for 
6  the agency to comply.”  Dkt. No. 120 (Pars) at 11.  In Montilla, a remand to the Board of 
7  Immigration Appeals made sense because petitioner’s sole contention on appeal was that “the 
8  immigration judge did not follow the applicable regulation protecting an alien’s right to counsel, 8 
9  C.F.R. § 242.16(a) (1990), and that this error constituted a denial of due process” in his 
10  deportation proceeding.  926 F.2d at 166, 170.  The Montilla court never said that a remand was 
11  the only option for an Accardi violation; to the contrary, it emphasized that the doctrine was “still 
12  alive and well” and that it was a “judicially-evolved rule ensuring fairness.”  Id. at 168.  This 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  underscores the flexibility inherent in the doctrine to fashion a remedy that fits the wrong.  
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  Montilla is also notable for applying Accardi as a freestanding claim, untethered to the 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  APA or other statute.  This is entirely consistent with the decision in Accardi itself, which was not 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  based on the APA.  See United States ex rel. Accardi v. Shaughnessy, 347 U.S. 260 (1954).  The 
S d nr
ee 17  Court has reached the same conclusion as Montilla that an Accardi claim can stand on its own and 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  “is at heart a claim of procedural fairness that owes as much to the Due Process Clause as to the 
19  Administrative Procedures Act.”  Dkt. No. 122 (Emami) at 2 (citing Jefferson v. Harris, 285 F. 
20  Supp. 3d 173, 185 (D.D.C. 2018)).  Plaintiffs’ decision to tie their Accardi claim to the APA is 
21  analytically questionable, and they may find that they have imposed on themselves unnecessary 
22  burdens by doing that.  The request to dismiss the Pars plaintiffs’ second claim under the Accardi 
23  doctrine is denied.   
24  4.  Fifth Amendment Due Process Claim 
25  Plaintiffs’ third claim directly under the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment for a 
26  violation of procedural due process cannot go forward.  In the Emami order, the Court dismissed 
27  this claim due to plaintiffs’ “inability to allege a deprivation of an interest protected by the Due 
28  Process Clause.”  Dkt. No. 74 (Emami) at 17.  This is a separate and different inquiry from the one 
6

2  “reconsider its view,” Dkt. No. 125 (Pars) at 12, on the basis of a circuit decision from 2008.  See 
3  id. at 12-13 (citing Bustamante v. Mukasey, 531 F.3d 1059 (9th Cir. 2008)).  This is also an 
4  improper request for reconsideration, and it is unpersuasive in that Bustamante pre-dates Kerry v. 
5  Din, 135 S.Ct. 2128 (2015), the main basis for the Court’s prior order on this issue, by nearly a 
6  decade.  The third claim is dismissed.

N 18  waiver applications.  Id. ¶ 337.  But “[m]andamus is an extraordinary remedy and is available to 
19  compel a federal official to perform a duty only if: (1) the individual’s claim is clear and certain; 
20  (2) the official’s duty is nondiscretionary, ministerial, and so plainly prescribed as to be free from 
21  doubt, and (3) no other adequate remedy is available.”  Kildare v. Saenz, 325 F.3d 1078, 1084 (9th 
22  Cir. 2003); see also Heckler v. Ringer, 466 U.S. 602, 616 (1984) (“The common-law writ of 
23  mandamus, as codified in 28 U.S.C. § 1361, is intended to provide a remedy for a plaintiff only if 
24  he has exhausted all other avenues of relief and only if the defendant owes him a clear 
25  nondiscretionary duty.”).  Plaintiffs do not identify any source of law that mandates that decisions 
26  be issued within a certain period of time, and the decisions on individual waiver applications are 
27  inherently discretionary.  See 82 Fed. Reg. at 45168 (“a consular officer, or the Commissioner,

3  II.  SUMMARY JUDGMENT 
4  The government’s motions for summary judgment are denied.  The government relies on 
5  an “administrative record” to “show[] that defendants have applied the waiver provision in an 
6  orderly way.”  Dkt. No. 98 (Emami) at 11.  But this does not account for the Accardi claims, and 
7  “there is no ‘administrative record’ when the essence of the claim is that the government has failed 
8  to act in accordance with its own rules and regulations.”  Dkt. No. 122 (Emami) at 2.  In addition, 
9  the multiple discovery dispute letters that have been filed in these cases underscore the degree to 
10  which the parties disagree about the material facts and what the “administrative record” might 
11  properly contain.  These factual disputes preclude summary judgment at this time.  See Federal 
12  Trade Commission v. D-Link Systems, Inc., No. 17-cv-00039-JD, 2018 WL 6040192 (N.D. Cal.
